CME.Description: CME-711 is a Trojan Downloader that is spread as an attachment to emails with news headlines as the subject lines which downloads additional security threats,
CME-416 is a multi-component mass-mailing worm that downloads and executes files from the Internet.

CME-762 is a worm that opens an IRC back door on the compromised host. It spreads by exploiting the Microsoft Windows Server Service Remote Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (Microsoft Security Bulletin MS06-040).

CME-482 is a worm that opens an IRC back door on the compromised host. It spreads by exploiting the Microsoft Windows Server Service Remote Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (Microsoft Security Bulletin MS06-040).
CME-136 is a Microsoft Word macro virus that drops a trojan onto the infected host.
CME-476 is a Microsoft Word macro virus that drops a trojan onto the infected host.
CME-745 is a Microsoft Word macro virus that drops a trojan onto the infected host.
This is small Trojan downloader that downloads files and lowers security settings. It is spreading as an email attachment.
This is a worm under Macintosh OS X that spreads via the iChat instant messaging application.
This is a "Bagle" mass-mailer which demonstrates typical "Bagle" behavior: it has a .ZIP file attachment, it contains a simple message subject/body, and it spreads to others.

This worm will destroy certain data files on an infected user's machine on Friday, February 3, 2006. Additional information can be found at: http://blogs.securiteam.com http://isc.sans.org/blackworm http://www.lurhq.com/blackworm.html
Trojan downloader that is spread as an attachment to a spam email and tries to download a password stealer.
A new variant of the Sober mass-mailing worm.
A new variant of the Sober mass-mailing worm.
A backdoor Trojan that is remotely controlled via Internet Relay Chat (IRC). It exploits Sony BMG Digital Rights Management (DRM) software to hide its presence.
This is a mass-mailing worm that uses its own SMTP engine to spread. It sends itself as an email attachment that mimics an image file.

A worm that opens a back door and exploits the Microsoft Windows Plug and Play Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS05-039 at http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/Bulletin/MS05-039.mspx) on TCP port 445.
A worm that spreads by exploiting Microsoft Windows Plug and Play Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (described in ).

A worm that opens a back door and exploits the Microsoft Windows Plug and Play Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS05-039 at http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/Bulletin/MS05-039.mspx) on TCP port 445.

A worm that spreads by exploiting the Microsoft Windows Plug and Play Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS05-039 at http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/Bulletin/MS05-039.mspx).

A worm that spreads by exploiting the Microsoft Windows Plug and Play Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS05-039 http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/Bulletin/MS05-039.mspx).

A mass-mailing worm that opens a back door, downloads remote files, and lowers security settings on the compromised computer. The worm spreads by exploiting the Microsoft Windows Plug and Play Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (as described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS05-039 at http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/Bulletin/MS05-039.mspx) and by sending a copy of itself to email addresses gathered.

A mass-mailing worm that opens a back door and exploits the Microsoft Windows Plug and Play Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (as described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS05-039 at http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/Bulletin/MS05-039.mspx) on TCP port 445.

A worm that opens a back door and exploits the Microsoft Windows Plug and Play Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (described Microsoft Security Bulletin MS05-039 at in http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/Bulletin/MS05-039.mspx) on TCP port 445.

A worm that opens a back door and exploits the Microsoft Windows Plug and Play Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS05-039 http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/Bulletin/MS05-039.mspx) on TCP port 445.

A worm that opens a back door and exploits the Microsoft Windows Plug and Play Buffer Overflow Vulnerability (described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS05-039 at http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/Bulletin/MS05-039.mspx) on TCP port 445.

A mass-mailing worm that uses its own SMTP engine to email copies of itself to addresses gathered from the compromised computer. The worm also opens a back door on TCP Port 9030 on the compromised computer.

A mass-mailing worm that opens a back door and attempts to propagate by exploiting the Microsoft Windows Local Security Authority Service Remote Buffer Overflow (as described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS04-011) on TCP port 445.
A trojan downloader.
A password stealing trojan that downloads a dll, which is used to intercept user keystrokes. The collected data is posted to another web site.
A trojan downloader that downloads an executable from a malware Web site.
A trojan that downloads adware and spyware programs on the infected system.
A trojan downloader that downloads malware from several different Internet addresses.
A Trojan horse that interferes with the operation of security software by ending processes, stopping services, removing registry entries, and deleting files.
A mass-mailing worm that sends itself as an email attachment to addresses gathered from the compromised computer. It uses its own SMTP engine to spread. The email may be in either English or German.
A mass-mailing worm arrives in an email messages that is designed to trick users into thinking that someone else is receiving their email.

A variant of the Mydoom worm. It spreads via email through SMTP, gathering target recipients from the Windows Address Book, the Temporary Internet Files folder, and certain fixed drives. Notably, it skips email addresses that contain certain strings.

A worm that spreads as an attachment to an infected email. The worm harvests addresses from the local address book and installs a proxy server. This Bagle variant spreads either as Windows PE EXE file or a Windows Control Panel Applet (CPL) file, both about 20 KB in size.
A variant of the Bagle worm.
